piece:
Hi all, I am a writer and have been for many years since I was a kid. I remember a day in college where I was talking to another student about how I’ve written something before. And when I told them it wasn’t even good, they just let out a disappointed “Oh.” Like it wasn’t anything special. 

Look, I put a lot of time and effort into my writing. Fanfiction or not. And to hear someone just sound so disappointed just... hurts me a bit. It took me over a year to complete that story. Which quickly turned into a trilogy. 

I just don’t get why writing fanfics is so looked down upon. Technically it is your own work, right? You’re just using someone else’s characters. So I don’t see the big deal here. Has anyone experienced anything like this? Should I just write my own characters? I feel like I wasted a lot of time on this. I just don’t get why writing fanfics

Evaluation Form (scores ONLY):

- Originality (1-3):

piece: In the dark and silence of my apartment, I heard a small noise outside my window. I opened my eyes, looked out my window, and there I saw someone else than myself. They were carrying something, and I was wondering what it was. When they closed their eyes I saw a small poem written on the wall. I opened my mouth to say something, but nothing came out, afterall. I just stood there. Looking out my window, my back turned to the world, my apartment full of people, and I just stood there. It was a small poem, but it was well written. I gave it my best explanation, that is, I gave it my life. I told them everything I knew up until I met them, and they all just made sense to me now. I knew them already because I had them in my heart. I loved them already because I had them in my soul. I wouldn’t know them from anywhere else. They were already there before me.

piece:
When I was twelve, my English teacher decided to educate the class on life’s inescapable expiry date. She began snapping her fingers in a steady rhythm, speaking light heartedly; ‘every time I click, someone has died’.
She talked as if it was no more than an interesting headline in her morning paper.
‘Dead. Dead. Dead. Dead.’ she chanted, before continuing to lecture us on some insignificant verse, clicking all the while.
Something about her breezy demeanor didn’t sit well with my younger self, like I couldn’t quite bring myself to whittle down someone’s final moments to the snap of my fingers.
And now, as I plummet towards the approaching concrete, I wonder if someone, somewhere, will click for me when I hit the ground. Will I miss them? Will I find them? Will I understand them? Will I be able to talk to them about the things I saw in the dark? The

piece: When you first met me, I was 17 and you were 31. I was drawn to you immediately because of how you looked. I saw you in a bookstore and I bought the book. You told me you wanted to read it, but you didn't. I left the store happy, because I knew you were serious about reading it. I walked away knowing you were going to be my author. I would like to meet you and chat about your book, but I have been so busy writing other things. I would love to read it again, and maybe even finish it. I have no idea how to write well enough, or even if I should even try. I know you are trying, and I admire your tenacity. I wish I could meet you and chat about your book, but I am so busy writing other things. I would love to read it again, and maybe even finish it. I have no idea how to write well enough, or even if I should even try.

I was still woke up from a deep slumber, and you were already gone.

I only know now that you were gone when I was most needed you most.

When I had no energy, you were there to give me energy.

When I had no desire, you were there to give me desire.

When I had no chance, you were there to give me chance.

I was so happy when you were gone, and then you came back.

I was so sad when you were gone, and then you came back.

I wish you could hug me like that forever.

I love you, sweetheart.

I will always love you.

Unlike you, I know now that you were there

piece:
Hi all, just looking for recommendations of online coursers for somebody like me, that is passionate about writing and wants to get published. I know most of us have read somewhere online or somewhere else and enjoyed that we couldn’t get enough of it. It takes time to write good pieces but most importantly, it involves dedicated research. Content quality breeds pleasure when read and it is a result of proper research.

To achieve content quality that’s engaging for the readers, you need to conduct proper research, analysis, and presentation of ideas.

When I was writing my research project as an undergraduate student, my supervisor emphasized the importance of proper research and presentation of ideas. He would regularly tell me that writing was like knitting where every knot was crucial to the whole process.  A single cumbersome knot was enough to compromise the whole process just like a misplaced idea adversely impacts the cohesion in a paragraph.

So, how do we conduct research to ensure that our writing flows and engages the readers
